q01.question:
A ____ is a synchronization primitive that consists of an ____ value that we can manipulate with two routines:
  1. ____: This function decrements the value of the semaphore and waits if the value of the semaphore is negative.
  2. ____: This function increments the value of the semaphore and then wakes up any waiting threads.

q02.question: Regarding using semaphores to implement locks and condition variables, which of the following statements are true (choose all that apply)?

responses.lock_init: To make a lock (binary semaphore), we initialize the semaphore to 1.
responses.cond_init: To make a condition variable, we initialize the semaphore to 1.
responses.lock_call: To make a lock (binary semaphore), we first <tt>sem_post</tt>, perform the critical section, and then <tt>sem_wait</tt>
responses.cond_call: To make a condition variable, we use <tt>sem_post</tt> to signal and <tt>sem_wait</tt> to wait.

q03.question: Regarding reader-writer locks, which of the following statements are true (choose all that apply)?

responses.concurrency: Reader-writer locks allow for multiple concurrent readers as long as there are no writers.
responses.writers: Reader-writer locks suspend all readers once a writer requires access.
responses.starvation: Reader-writer locks are prone to starvation problems.
responses.overhead: Reader-writer locks generally improve performance over simple and fast locking primitives.

q04.question:
Suppose you and your friends are going slacklining. Unfortunately, the slackline can only support up to three people on it at a time.  Therefore, if they are many people, they will need to wait before they can get onto the slackline.

Assuming each person performs the following procedure:

get_on()          // Get on slackline if there is enough room
do_slack_line()   // Attempt to walk across slackline
get_off()         // Get off of slackline

Model this synchronization problem using POSIX threads, mutexes, or condition variables. Assume each person is represented as a thread that calls the functions above to get on the slackline, cross the slackline, and then get off the slackline.

Assuming the following global variables:

size_t CAPACITY = 3  // Maximum number of people on slackline
size_t Slackers = 0  // Current number of people on slackline

Mutex  Lock     
Cond   Line

Select and order the following lines of code to implement each of the functions below:

A. mutex_lock(Lock)
B. mutex_unlock(Lock)
C. cond_wait(Line, Lock)
D. cond_signal(Line)
E. while Slackers >= CAPACITY
F. while Slackers < CAPACITY
G. Slackers++
H. Slackers--

  1. Select and order the lines of code above to implement the get_on() function. ____
  2. Select and order the lines of code above to implement the get_off() function. ____

Put a single space between each line of code (ie. "A B C")).

q05.question: To solve the Dining Philosopher's problem, the book proposes the following solution:

responses.order: Change the order in which the last philosopher acquires the forks.
responses.waiter: Have a waiter direct which philosophers can eat.
responses.starve: Just let some of the philosophers starve.
responses.rdrn: Have philosophers eat in round-robin fashion.

q06.question:
Two types of non-deadlock concurrency bugs are:
  1. ____: These bugs occur when the assumption of atomicity is incorrect.
  2. ____: These bugs occur when the desired order of operations is not enforced during execution.

q07.question:
Deadlock occurs when the following four conditions hold:
  1. ____: There exists a circular chain of threads such that each thread holds one or more resources that are being requested by the next thread in the chain.
  2. ____: Resources cannot be forcibly removed from threads that are holding them.
  3. ____: Threads hold resources allocated to them while waiting for additional resources.
  4. ____: Threads claim exclusive control of resources that they require.

q08.question: Which of the following are ways to prevent deadlock (choose all that apply)?

responses.ordering: Provide some form of ordering to circumvent circular waiting.
responses.holding: Make sure we always acquire locks one at a time.
responses.livelock: Prefer methods that utilize livelock instead of deadlock.
responses.lockfree: Avoid locks by using atomic hardware instructions.

q09.question: Rather than prevent deadlock, we can instead try to avoid it by having a smart ____ that will consider the dependencies between threads or by having a service that ____ deadlock and provides ____ techniques.

q10.question:
Suppose you and your friends are going to Salsa night hosted by our beloved Ramzi. You are willing to dance, but only after at least 2 of your friends have started dancing.

Model this synchronization problem using POSIX threads and semaphores. Assume each person is represented as a thread that calls one of the corresponding functions below (you_dance() for yourself and friend_dance() for each of your friends).

Assuming the following global variables:

size_t MIN_FRIENDS = 2  // Minimum number of friends dancing before you will dance
size_t Friends     = 0  // Number of friends dancing

Semaphore Lock     = 1
Semaphore Dancing  = 0

Select and order the following lines of code to implement each of the functions below:

A. sem_wait(Lock)
B. sem_post(Lock)
C. sem_wait(Dancing)
D. sem_post(Dancing)
E. Friends++
F. Friends--
G. if Friends >= MIN_FRIENDS
H. if Friends < MIN_FRIENDS

  1. Select and order the lines of code above to implement the you_dance() function. ____
  2. Select and order the lines of code above to implement the friend_dance() function. ____

Put a single space between each line of code (ie. "A B C")).
